summary: Stocks snapped a four-day winning streak as investors tempered some of their recent bullishness, buying up Treasurys and sending gold prices to an exchange record.

summary: Is time running out for the bond rally that has lasted 30 years so far? With rates at zero and yields at record lows, bond-market bears warn that the clock is ticking—but that might be too simplistic.

summary: The Obama administration believes momentum is growing in the Senate toward ratifying a revamped nuclear arms-control treaty with Russia, one of President Barack Obama's top foreign-policy objectives.

headline: Dell Flips the Tablet Concept Around
summary: Dell introduces Windows tablet that comes with a keyboard and may be essentially turned into a standard laptop.

headline: Tanzanian Wants to Testify on Bombing
summary: A man who claims he supplied dynamite used in the bombing of a U.S. Embassy in Tanzania willingly wants to testify at the trial of the first Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, detainee to face trial in the U.S., a federal agent testified.

summary: Two former Brooklyn, N.Y., residents charged earlier this year with conspiring to provide computer advice and other material support to al Qaeda have been indicted on additional charges, prosecutors said.

summary: A federal judge approved $37.6 million in legal fees in connection with the liquidation of Madoff's investment firm, over the objections of some victims.

summary: Fashion models' manicures, hair styles and makeup colors are triggering retail trends. Two designers, Tracy Reese and Prabal Gurung have made hair and nail work essential parts of their runway shows.

summary: While I support free trade, I am also an ardent believer in the doctrine of payment by the perpetrator, not by the victims of unintended consequences.

summary: Michigan's Denard Robinson leads the nation in rushing - but can a quarterback sustain that pounding for a full season?

summary: INSEAD business school said it named Dipak Jain, a former dean of Northwestern University's Kellogg School of Management, its new dean, effective March 2011.

summary: European stocks ended a choppy session nearly flat, supported by better-than-expected U.S. economic data. Asia indexes ended mixed with Tokyo stocks falling as exporters wilted under the pressure of a rising yen.

summary: Crude futures eased lower as uncertainty about the status of a major Canada-U.S. oil pipeline weighed on the market.

summary: The sky-high Swiss franc shot up to parity against the dollar for the first time since a spell of broad-based dollar weakness in December 2009.

summary: AIG's pan-Asian life-insurance unit AIA Group named Marc de Cure as chief financial officer, removing one of the big question marks hanging over its planned initial public offering.

headline: A Designer Prepares
summary: Before the show, designer Christian Cota gets ready for Spring 2011 Fashion Week

headline: Senate Defeats GOP Bid to Lift Tax-Reporting Rule

headline: Akzo Loses Ruling on Legal Privilege
summary: Europe's highest court held that advice from in-house lawyers isn't covered by attorney-client privilege, ending a bid by Akzo Nobel to broaden the doctrine.

summary: U.S. retail sales rose for a second consecutive month, increasing 0.4% in August as shoppers flocked to back-to-school sales and took advantage of tax-free shopping promotions.

summary: A group of centrist House Democrats will call for a short-term extension of tax cuts for upper-income Americans, adding to growing pressure on Democratic leaders on the issue.

headline: TPG in Talks for Stake in Russia's VTB
summary: U.S. private equity firm TPG is in preliminary talks to buy a stake of up to 10% in Russian state-controlled bank VTB Group from the government, a person familiar with the talks said.

summary: The Business Roundtable, which released a survey of members, is urging the Obama administration to put forth all-inclusive job growth policies, as opposed to offering measures targeted specifically at small businesses.

summary: The new China-based owners of Volvo plan to build as many as three assembly plants in that country—betting that the company can almost double sales globally.
